description:
⁠
These types of behaviors occur most often in our closest relationships.  This is because our closest relationships reveal our deepest wounds. ⁠
⁠
The pain and fear that results causes us to try to control others in an attempt to minimize the pain and protect our wounds.  When we have unmet needs, it can be easy to engage in unsupportive, manipulative, and weaponized behavior. ⁠
⁠
We usually default to the behaviors we used as a child to receive attention or to the patterns our parents modeled for us. ⁠
⁠
Unfortunately, control strategies become a substitute for vulnerable and open communication, establishing boundaries, and fostering support.  And they end up damaging our relationships in big ways. ⁠
⁠
When you learn to set healthy boundaries with yourself and others, you will feel safe enough to let go of the need to control.  In relinquishing control, we enable ourselves to find true connection and freedom. ⁠
⁠
We respond best to positive affirmation and loving requests, as opposed to criticism, contempt, blame, stonewalling, and defensiveness. ⁠
⁠
Express your needs and desires to your partner clearly and calmly.  This can feel scary and vulnerable if your needs were not heard and validated a s a child.  Let your frustration out in ways that don’t hurt your partner. ⁠
⁠
And remember, it took time for you to learn these behaviors and it will likely take time to unlearn them and relearn new behaviors.  Be gentle with yourself. ⁠
⁠
What are some other ways we try to control others? ⁠
⁠
Let’s #healtogether
